article.headline: Michael Cohen casts himself as âstar witnessâ against Trump in new memoir
article.body: NEW YORK â Michael Cohenâs tell-all memoir makes the case that President Donald Trump is âguilty of the same crimesâ that landed his former fixer in federal prison, offering a blow-by-blow account of Trumpâs alleged role in a hush money scandal that once overshadowed his presidency. Of all the crises Cohen confronted working for Trump, none proved as vexing as the porn actress Stormy Daniels and her claims of an extramarital affair with Trump, Cohen writes in âDisloyal: The True Story of the Former Personal Attorney to President Donald J. Trump.â Trump, despite his later protestations, green-lighted the $130,000 payment to silence Daniels ahead of the 2016 election, reasoning he would âhave to payâ his wife a far greater sum if the affair ever became known, Cohen writes, adding the president later reimbursed him with âfake legal fees.â âIt never pays to settle these things, but many, many friends have advised me to pay,â Trump said, according to Cohen. âIf it comes out, Iâm not sure how it would play with my supporters. But I bet theyâd think itâs cool that I slept with a porn star.â The White House called Cohenâs memoir âfan fiction.â âHe readily admits to lying routinely but expects people to believe him now so that he can make money from book sales,â White House spokesman Brian Morgenstern said in a statement. âItâs unfortunate that the media is exploiting this sad and desperate man to attack President Trump.â The Associated Press obtained an early copy of the book, which is scheduled to be released Tuesday. Cohen, who pleaded guilty to campaign-finance violations and other crimes, including lying to Congress, calls himself the âstar witnessâ of a hush-money conspiracy that still could culminate in charges for Trump after he leaves office. He described his new book as a âfundamental piece of evidenceâ of the presidentâs guilt. In an interview with NBCâs Lester Holt last week, Cohen said he fears Trump would now do anything to stay in power, laying out prospective scenarios, and adding that a peaceful transition of power after a Trump loss on Nov. 3 is not a certainty. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Cohenâs allegations â his most detailed to date â are part of an unsparing and deeply personal take-down attempt on Trump. Cohen assails Trump as an âorganized crime donâ and âmaster manipulator,â but allows that he saw much of himself in a man he once considered a father figure. âI care for Donald Trump, even to this day,â Cohen writes, âand I had and still have a lot of affection for him.â Cohen remains at a loss to explain his unswerving allegiance to a cutthroat businessman who abandoned him at the most vulnerable point in his life. He likens his fealty to Trump to a mental illness and said he thought of himself as acting like a drug user in need of an intervention. âIt seemed to [my family] that I wouldnât listen to anyone, not even the people who loved me most, as I gradually gave up control of my mind to Trump,â Cohen writes. âI confess I never really did understand why pleasing Trump meant so much to me,â Cohen adds. âTo this day I donât have the full answer.â The memoir offers an introspective â and at times self-loathing â apology for the role Cohen played in Trumpâs political ascent. He urged Trump for years to run for president but now laments that his election âled the nation and maybe even the world to the brink of disaster.â Key Words (January 2019):Michael Cohen confirms he paid tech firm to rig polls and says Trump directed him to do it âI thought Trump was a visionary with a no-nonsense attitude and the charisma to attract all kinds of voters,â he writes. But the real reason he wanted Trump in the White House, Cohen concedes, âwas because I wanted the power that he would bring to me.â Cohen expresses little to no remorse for his federal crimes, saying he was ârailroadedâ by the government and pleaded guilty after prosecutors threatened to indict his wife. He writes that Trumpâs three oldest children came to Cohenâs office after Trumpâs campaign announcement in 2015, in which Trump referred to people coming to the U.S. from Mexico as rapists and murderers. Cohen says they asked him to convince their father to drop out of the race, arguing his rhetoric was âkilling the company.â Cohen says Trump was unconcerned with any harm to his businesses. âPlus, I will never get the Hispanic vote,â Trump said, according to Cohen. âLike the blacks, theyâre too stupid to vote for Trump. Theyâre not my people.â Cohen returns to Trumpâs treatment of women throughout the book. He describes the married Trump ogling contestants at his Miss Universe pageant and boasting he could âhave all of themâ if he wanted. He also claimed to have seen Trump corner and forcibly kiss women at his office. In a far more personal episode, Cohen writes of Trump leering at Cohenâs daughter at Trumpâs New Jersey golf club in 2012. Cohen writes that when he told Trump that it was his daughter he was ogling, Trump replied: âWhen did she get so hot?â She was 15 years old at the time. Cohen also sheds light on Trumpâs admiration of Russian President Vladimir Putin, saying he admired him most because he âhad the balls to take over an entire nation and run it like it was his personal company.â He characterizes Trumpâs campaign as, in his view, âfar too chaotic and incompetent to actually conspire with the Russian government.â Beyond his dealings with Trump, Cohen waxes nostalgic about experiences he says informed his fierce loyalty and attack-dog persona. The Long Island native, a Holocaust survivorâs son, writes of rubbing shoulders with mobsters at his uncleâs club, where he worked as a teen. After witnessing a poolside shooting, he says he felt a duty to keep quiet. A few days later, he writes, a tough-looking fellow handed him an envelope stuffed with $500 in cash. Cohen has led a publicity blitz around his memoir even as he serves his federal sentence in home confinement. A judge ruled this summer that authorities had retaliated against him, sending him back to prison in upstate New York after he was furloughed because of the coronavirus pandemic, for publishing the book ahead of the November election. Cohen was released to home confinement in July and the government lifted a ban on him speaking publicly. âThis story is all I have left for my wife, my children and the country I love so much,â Cohen writes. MarketWatch contributed.
